values.title: Building Editor: Auto-expand 2D canvas when user tries to draw beyond screen

content.raw: If the user, while drawing a wall, brings the mouse to the edge of the 2D View, the canvas should become larger. The same is true when the user moves an existing object(s) to the edge of the 2D View.
content.html: If the user, while drawing a wall, brings the mouse to the edge of the 2D View, the canvas should become larger. The same is true when the user moves an existing object(s) to the edge of the 2D View.

values.title: Add Undo feature to Gazebo

content.raw:
Allow user to Ctrl+Z or select the Back arrow in the Toolbar to undo a change.

All users in Align/Snap usability test tried to Undo at least one action.
content.html:
Allow user to Ctrl+Z or select the Back arrow in the Toolbar to undo a change.

All users in Align/Snap usability test tried to Undo at least one action.

values.title: Building Editor: When duplicating levels, don't duplicate interior walls

content.raw: Only duplicate exterior floor plan
content.html: Only duplicate exterior floor plan

values.title: collada texture transparency bug

content.raw:
When adding a collada file with transparent textures I have to view the object in transparent mode first in order to make it load (more or less) correctly. Before setting the model to transparent the textures are rendered incorrectly and transparency is ignored. After setting the model to transparent and back loading additional instances of the object show up correctly (when loading multiple instances and viewing one transparent it also makes the other one transparent however, this is probably related to #259). 

The model shows up as expected/desired transparency wise when viewing it in transparent mode (just the ordering of transparent parts is incorrect sometimes), but after disabling transparency mode it does not render the transparent parts of the texture correct anymore. My example object is a tree with different layers for leaves and the transparent parts of those layers often render all the way through to the floor or trunk ignoring other transparent parts behind them.

See this video for a better understanding (tree1 was exported using sketchup6 and tree2 using sketchup8):  http://youtu.be/01VJa_z7SIY
The model is available here: http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=772012e0183084608da3b5c4427262d1&prevstart=0
content.html:
When adding a collada file with transparent textures I have to view the object in transparent mode first in order to make it load (more or less) correctly. Before setting the model to transparent the textures are rendered incorrectly and transparency is ignored. After setting the model to transparent and back loading additional instances of the object show up correctly (when loading multiple instances and viewing one transparent it also makes the other one transparent however, this is probably related to #259).

The model shows up as expected/desired transparency wise when viewing it in transparent mode (just the ordering of transparent parts is incorrect sometimes), but after disabling transparency mode it does not render the transparent parts of the texture correct anymore. My example object is a tree with different layers for leaves and the transparent parts of those layers often render all the way through to the floor or trunk ignoring other transparent parts behind them.

See this video for a better understanding (tree1 was exported using sketchup6 and tree2 using sketchup8): http://youtu.be/01VJa_z7SIY The model is available here: http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=772012e0183084608da3b5c4427262d1&prevstart=0

values.title: Building Editor: Allow user to exit Draw mode without drawing

content.raw: To exit draw mode, let user “toggle” Draw Wall button off OR click on empty space in the Palette to disengage draw mode (support both). Currently, user lacks control over which mode they're in (which is bad)
content.html: To exit draw mode, let user “toggle” Draw Wall button off OR click on empty space in the Palette to disengage draw mode (support both). Currently, user lacks control over which mode they're in (which is bad)

values.title: Building Editor: Add directional arrow to stair icon in 2D view

content.raw: So users know which way is up
content.html: So users know which way is up

values.title: Building Editor: Make door placement depend on direction wall is approached

content.raw: The door opening direction should adjust based on which side of the wall the user approaches from when adding the door (i.e. cursor comes from right side of wall, the door opens facing off the right of the wall)
content.html: The door opening direction should adjust based on which side of the wall the user approaches from when adding the door (i.e. cursor comes from right side of wall, the door opens facing off the right of the wall)

values.title: Building Editor: Add XY hotkeys for moving objects in 2D View

content.raw: So users can move objects in constrained motion
content.html: So users can move objects in constrained motion

values.title: Building Editor: Give users more control over doors

content.raw: Once hinges are added, allow users to dictate the hinge location on the door, and the degree of the door opening
content.html: Once hinges are added, allow users to dictate the hinge location on the door, and the degree of the door opening

values.title: Building Editor: Let users add billboards

content.raw: Allow users to import images and affix them to the walls
content.html: Allow users to import images and affix them to the walls

values.title: Building Editor: Let users add existing models to the building

content.raw: This will allow users to create more complex buildings (with furniture, etc)
content.html: This will allow users to create more complex buildings (with furniture, etc)

values.title: Building Editor: Add Roof option to Palette

content.raw: Provide a couple of roof styles
content.html: Provide a couple of roof styles

values.title: Building Editor: Adding levels is confusing

content.raw: When a new level is added, zoom out enough in the 3D View so that the user can see the level being added in the 3D View. It's easy to not realize that clicking the Plus button has in fact added a level.
content.html: When a new level is added, zoom out enough in the 3D View so that the user can see the level being added in the 3D View. It's easy to not realize that clicking the Plus button has in fact added a level.

values.title: Building Editor: Consider placing the Palette as a Toolbar in 2D View

content.raw: This will free up some screen space, and mirror the Toolbar in the 3D View
content.html: This will free up some screen space, and mirror the Toolbar in the 3D View

values.title: Building Editor: Layering issue

content.raw:
There seems to be a layering issue. When an object (wall, window, door) is within the bounding box of a wall, it's not possible to select that object. 

Relatedly, the end markers of a wall sometimes get hidden beneath another wall
content.html:
There seems to be a layering issue. When an object (wall, window, door) is within the bounding box of a wall, it's not possible to select that object.

Relatedly, the end markers of a wall sometimes get hidden beneath another wall

values.title: Building Editor: Wall segments should not all delete when one is deleted

content.raw: If multiple walls are created as one continuous segment, selecting and deleting a single wall section deletes all attached walls. This should not happen: only the selected wall should be deleted.
content.html: If multiple walls are created as one continuous segment, selecting and deleting a single wall section deletes all attached walls. This should not happen: only the selected wall should be deleted.

values.title: Building Editor: Inspectors disappear behind Gazebo window

content.raw: When an Inspector is open, clicking somewhere in the Gazebo window sends the Inspector to the back and out of view. The Inspector should stay on top of the Gazebo window until the Inspector is closed/dismissed.
content.html: When an Inspector is open, clicking somewhere in the Gazebo window sends the Inspector to the back and out of view. The Inspector should stay on top of the Gazebo window until the Inspector is closed/dismissed.

values.title: Building Editor: After Save As is clicked, change button label to Save

content.raw: Once the user has Save As'd the building, the button label should change to Save
content.html: Once the user has Save As'd the building, the button label should change to Save

values.title: Wiki favicon missing

content.raw:
The gazebosim favicon is missing for the media wiki installation. 

Without it finding the gazebosim wiki browser tab becomes more difficult.
content.html:
The gazebosim favicon is missing for the media wiki installation.

Without it finding the gazebosim wiki browser tab becomes more difficult.

values.title: gazebo segfaults during startup

content.raw:
While starting pr2 gazebo simulation, occasionally `gzserver` segfaults (1 out of 5 tries for me so far).  The last call in gazebo before entering Ogre appears to be:
~~~
#14 0x00007ffff28e6189 in gazebo::rendering::Light::CreateVisual (this=0x3a948f0)

content.html:
While starting pr2 gazebo simulation, occasionally gzserver segfaults (1 out of 5 tries for me so far). The last call in gazebo before entering Ogre appears to be:

#14 0x00007ffff28e6189 in gazebo::rendering::Light::CreateVisual (this=0x3a948f0)
    at /home/hsu/ros_groovy/simulator_gazebo/gazebo/build/gazebo-hg/gazebo/rendering/Light.cc:285

The full back trace is found below:

values.title: Provide Schema for SDF files

content.raw: In order to simplify importing and exporting SDF files in other projects as well as validating the SDF files, it is useful to have a [XML Schema](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XML_Schema_%28W3C%29) describing the structure of the XML file.
content.html: In order to simplify importing and exporting SDF files in other projects as well as validating the SDF files, it is useful to have a XML Schema describing the structure of the XML file.

values.title: Building Editor: Add Import Image feature (see specs)

content.raw: Allow users to upload a floorplan (or other image) that they can trace over.
content.html: Allow users to upload a floorplan (or other image) that they can trace over.

values.title: Make website links in Gazebo About box clickable

content.raw:
As of pull request #231, the Gazebo About box lists several website links, but they are not clickable (see attached image). Qt supports a [subset of HTML 4 text formatting](http://doc.qt.digia.com/qt/richtext-html-subset.html) through the use of the Qt::RichText format. The about box can be set to using the rich text format with the following line of code added to [MainWindow.cc around line 336](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/8e8c04b1746d242b34941f4762c9b41495195a3a/gazebo/gui/MainWindow.cc?at=update_about_dialog#cl-322): ~~~ aboutBox.setTextFormat(Qt::RichText); ~~~ This will require reformatting the About box text field in html (replace '\n' with
and tabs with tables or something) and adding tags to the website links.
content.html:
As of pull request #231, the Gazebo About box lists several website links, but they are not clickable (see attached image).

Qt supports a subset of HTML 4 text formatting through the use of the Qt::RichText format. The about box can be set to using the rich text format with the following line of code added to MainWindow.cc around line 336:

aboutBox.setTextFormat(Qt::RichText);

This will require reformatting the About box text field in html (replace '\n' with <br> and tabs with tables or something) and adding <a> tags to the website links.

values.title: add Entity::GetInitialRelativePose

content.raw: add accessor for `Entity::initialRelativePose`, used by RTQL8 during [Joint::Load](https://bitbucket.org/jlee02/gazebo/src/ca45bf0f8719b99a741e2c7ab9b86becb748ff36/gazebo/physics/rtql8/RTQL8HingeJoint.cc?at=rtql8#cl-47) for example.
content.html: add accessor for Entity::initialRelativePose, used by RTQL8 during Joint::Load for example.

values.title: Can't "see" the pioneer robot

content.raw:
1) Drop a pioneer into the world in front of the robot
2) open the camera view

The pioneer is not displayed correctly (only the wheels)

This was observed on my machine while running simulation with CloudSim, both machines using the prerelease debs

ii  drcsim-prerelease                       1.4.0                                   3D dynamics simulator for robotics

values.title: Changing z value of pose of object makes it disappear

content.raw:
Repro:
Run Gazebo
add a unit sphere
in "world" tab under "models" click on unit_sphere
in pose:
  - change the x position.  This works fine
  - change the z positon to 1.0.  Works, and sphere falls to ground.
  - in "link" set gravity to false
  - change the z position to 2.0.  Works. Sphere stays there.
  - change the z positoion to 0.0 (or any negative number).  Sphere disappears (seems to be flying quickly through the world).

Using  version:  1.7.6-s1357263943~precise
Installed from Ubuntu 12.04 (precise) as package ros-groovy-simulator-gazebo
content.html:
Repro: Run Gazebo add a unit sphere in "world" tab under "models" click on unit_sphere in pose: - change the x position. This works fine - change the z positon to 1.0. Works, and sphere falls to ground. - in "link" set gravity to false - change the z position to 2.0. Works. Sphere stays there. - change the z positoion to 0.0 (or any negative number). Sphere disappears (seems to be flying quickly through the world).

Using version: 1.7.6-s1357263943~precise Installed from Ubuntu 12.04 (precise) as package ros-groovy-simulator-gazebo

values.title: SDF geometry enhancements

content.raw:
A very common use case of SDF, involves links that have collision and visual elements that use the same geometry properties. Currently this involves duplicated information and manual synchronization. For example:
~~~
<link name="ball">
  <collision name="collision">
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>1</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
  </collision>
  <visual name="visual">
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>1</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
    <material>
      <script>Gazebo/Grey</script>
    </material>
  </visual>
</link>
~~~

I propose allowing a <geometry> element as a child of <link> that can be referenced by <collision> and <visual> elements. The above example could be re-written as:

~~~
<link name="ball">
  <geometry name="geom">
    <sphere>
      <radius>1</radius>
    </sphere>
  </geometry>
  <collision name="collision">
    <geometry inherit_from="geom"/>
  </collision>
  <visual name="visual">
    <geometry inherit_from="geom"/>
    <material>
      <script>Gazebo/Grey</script>
    </material>
  </visual>
</link>
~~~

I would also propose allowing the <inertia> tags to accept some geometry elements, which can be used to automatically compute the moment of inertia terms, assuming uniform density. For meshes, it could be based on the bounding box. For example, a ball with inertial parameters could be specified as:

~~~
<link name="ball">
  <geometry name="geom">
    <sphere>
      <radius>1</radius>
    </sphere>
  </geometry>
  <inertial>
    <mass>1</mass>
    <geometry inherit_from="geom"/>
  </inertial>
  <collision name="collision">
    <geometry inherit_from="geom"/>
  </collision>
  <visual name="visual">
    <geometry inherit_from="geom"/>
    <material>
      <script>Gazebo/Grey</script>
    </material>
  </visual>
</link>
~~~

One could also imagine the utility of allowing <geometry> elements as children of <model> elements so that a stack of identical boxes could each inherit the same geometric properties.
content.html:
A very common use case of SDF, involves links that have collision and visual elements that use the same geometry properties. Currently this involves duplicated information and manual synchronization. For example:

<link name="ball">
  <collision name="collision">
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>1</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
  </collision>
  <visual name="visual">
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>1</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
    <material>
      <script>Gazebo/Grey</script>
    </material>
  </visual>
</link>

I propose allowing a <geometry> element as a child of <link> that can be referenced by <collision> and <visual> elements. The above example could be re-written as:

<link name="ball">
  <geometry name="geom">
    <sphere>
      <radius>1</radius>
    </sphere>
  </geometry>
  <collision name="collision">
    <geometry inherit_from="geom"/>
  </collision>
  <visual name="visual">
    <geometry inherit_from="geom"/>
    <material>
      <script>Gazebo/Grey</script>
    </material>
  </visual>
</link>

I would also propose allowing the <inertia> tags to accept some geometry elements, which can be used to automatically compute the moment of inertia terms, assuming uniform density. For meshes, it could be based on the bounding box. For example, a ball with inertial parameters could be specified as:

<link name="ball">
  <geometry name="geom">
    <sphere>
      <radius>1</radius>
    </sphere>
  </geometry>
  <inertial>
    <mass>1</mass>
    <geometry inherit_from="geom"/>
  </inertial>
  <collision name="collision">
    <geometry inherit_from="geom"/>
  </collision>
  <visual name="visual">
    <geometry inherit_from="geom"/>
    <material>
      <script>Gazebo/Grey</script>
    </material>
  </visual>
</link>

One could also imagine the utility of allowing <geometry> elements as children of <model> elements so that a stack of identical boxes could each inherit the same geometric properties.

values.title: Double sided normals

content.raw: Properly import collada meshes that have double sided normals. And example is the stop_sign model, available in the vrc_arenas repo.
content.html: Properly import collada meshes that have double sided normals. And example is the stop_sign model, available in the vrc_arenas repo.

values.title: sdf::Element::Update doesn't update element values

content.raw:
The sdf::Param class allows update functions to be set for sdf elements and attributes. When sdf::Element::Update is called, these functions are called recursively. See [gazebo/physics/Inertia.cc:98](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3e5fb38a404efadc6e01eb5255178f94d8f2b3b3/gazebo/physics/Inertial.cc?at=default#cl-98) for an example.

Currently attributes are being updated properly, but element values are not. A failing test has been added in changeset a8abb5f.

There is a simple fix, and a pull request is forthcoming.
content.html:
The sdf::Param class allows update functions to be set for sdf elements and attributes. When sdf::Element::Update is called, these functions are called recursively. See gazebo/physics/Inertia.cc:98 for an example.

Currently attributes are being updated properly, but element values are not. A failing test has been added in changeset a8abb5f.

There is a simple fix, and a pull request is forthcoming.

values.title: MultiCameraSensor::GetCameraCount not implemented
Gazebo compilation broken without libgtest present

content.raw:
When performing a gazebo compilation in a clean system (minimal mandatory depedencies) without a libgtest-dev package installed, the compilation fails since a couple of CMakeLists.txt, into tests directories, lack of "include" directive for the embedded gtest version inside gazebo.

Attached is a patch for fixing this.

P.D: what about creating a jenkins for this kind of 'minimal dependencies' compilation?

values.title: CMake macro gz_build_test link tests unconditionally to all gazebo libraries

content.raw:
In ```gz_build_test``` CMake macro introduced in pull request #230, the input test file is going to be [linked against all gazebo libraries](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/230/fix-for-issue-365-warn-when-messages-are/diff#Lcmake/GazeboUtils.cmakeT159) which is not needed in most of the cases.

Speaking about the consequences of this massive linking, it will mean that all shared libraries are loaded in memory in the moment of execution. However, Ubuntu is passing automatically ```--as-needed``` flag to the linker, so load of unnecessary libraries is avoided. But this does not happen in all Linux distribution. So:

1.  We find a way of telling the macro what dependencies the test need
2.  We add the --as-needed flag in our cmake system. 

Correct solution should be only link against needed libraries. Second option could not work on some other non-Linux platforms.
content.html:
In gz_build_test CMake macro introduced in pull request #230, the input test file is going to be linked against all gazebo libraries which is not needed in most of the cases.

Speaking about the consequences of this massive linking, it will mean that all shared libraries are loaded in memory in the moment of execution. However, Ubuntu is passing automatically --as-needed flag to the linker, so load of unnecessary libraries is avoided. But this does not happen in all Linux distribution. So:

  1. We find a way of telling the macro what dependencies the test need
  2. We add the --as-needed flag in our cmake system.

Correct solution should be only link against needed libraries. Second option could not work on some other non-Linux platforms.

values.title: No method to delete a single element from sdf

content.raw:
There is no method to delete an element with its attributes and children from an sdf object. For example, consider the following example sdf:
~~~
<sdf>
<world>
  <model name="model1">...</model>
  <model name="model2">...</model>
</world>
</sdf>
~~~
There's no way to delete model2. You could try 
~~~
SDF::ElementPtr elem = sdf->root->GetElement("world")->GetElement("model");
while (elem->GetValueString("name") != "model2")
  elem = elem->GetNextElement("model");
~~~
until you have the right one, and then do a
~~~
elem->ClearElements();
~~~
This would still leave you with the husk of the model2 element:
~~~
<sdf>
<world>
  <model name="model1">...</model>
  <model name="model2"/>
</world>
</sdf>
~~~
content.html:
There is no method to delete an element with its attributes and children from an sdf object. For example, consider the following example sdf:

<sdf>
<world>
  <model name="model1">...</model>
  <model name="model2">...</model>
</world>
</sdf>

There's no way to delete model2. You could try 

SDF::ElementPtr elem = sdf->root->GetElement("world")->GetElement("model");
while (elem->GetValueString("name") != "model2")
  elem = elem->GetNextElement("model");

until you have the right one, and then do a

elem->ClearElements();

This would still leave you with the husk of the model2 element:

<sdf>
<world>
  <model name="model1">...</model>
  <model name="model2"/>
</world>
</sdf>

content.html:
/// \returns Returns DBL_MAX for no detection.
  public: double GetRange(int _index) const;

GetRange, GetRetro, GetFiducial should be const

values.title: Potential regression in Collada Parser for .dae files with unexpected triangle semantics

content.raw:
I recently started playing with some old URDFs with Collada meshes with Gazebo 1.3 via the ROS Groovy distribution. I found that it would segfault on some of the models if they had the "TEXTANGENT" and "TEXBINORMAL" semantics in a `<triangles>` tag. 

See this Collada file to see the behavior: [wamUpperArmInShoulderLink.DAE](https://github.com/jhu-lcsr/bard/blob/master/bard_urdf/models/componentSTL/wamUpperArmInShoulderLink.DAE#L144)

While the segfault happens in the `math::parseInt` it's actually caused by [ColladaLoader.cc:1321](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0c8b89b967826b4f9e45baa57d4cdabc3f8e4c56/gazebo/common/ColladaLoader.cc?at=default#cl-1321) when it accesses an out-of-bounds element of `strs`. It looks like it's because it's not parsing the input semantics properly. I'd submit a PR, but I'm not sure how that should be parsed either. 

That being said, the **current fix is to import the .dae into Blender and re-export.** It might be sufficient to catch that indexing error before it happens, and just display a warning message telling the user that those semantics aren't supported and they should re-export the file.
content.html:
I recently started playing with some old URDFs with Collada meshes with Gazebo 1.3 via the ROS Groovy distribution. I found that it would segfault on some of the models if they had the "TEXTANGENT" and "TEXBINORMAL" semantics in a <triangles> tag.

See this Collada file to see the behavior: wamUpperArmInShoulderLink.DAE

While the segfault happens in the math::parseInt it's actually caused by ColladaLoader.cc:1321 when it accesses an out-of-bounds element of strs. It looks like it's because it's not parsing the input semantics properly. I'd submit a PR, but I'm not sure how that should be parsed either.

That being said, the current fix is to import the .dae into Blender and re-export. It might be sufficient to catch that indexing error before it happens, and just display a warning message telling the user that those semantics aren't supported and they should re-export the file.

values.title: Loading some models influences scale of other models

content.raw:
When loading the new polaris ranger or one of the houses from the gazebo_models database some models' scale gets influenced such that a scaling factor of ~20 or ~40 is needed to scale it back to the desired scale. When loading the other model first and then the polaris, further instances of the model loaded after the polaris do not get influenced (which also leads me to the question whether Gazebo is using instancing for models?). 

Example:

 - 1) Load polaris, 2) load model X  --> model X shows up very tiny
 - 1) load model X, 2) load polaris, 3) load model X (either as a second instance or after deleting the first instance) --> both instances of model X show up at the expected size

Some example models that get influenced: 

 - assassin:  www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/assassins_creed.tar.gz
 - tree (btw you can also use this model for testing ticket #404):  www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/firtree.tar.gz
content.html:
When loading the new polaris ranger or one of the houses from the gazebo_models database some models' scale gets influenced such that a scaling factor of ~20 or ~40 is needed to scale it back to the desired scale. When loading the other model first and then the polaris, further instances of the model loaded after the polaris do not get influenced (which also leads me to the question whether Gazebo is using instancing for models?).

Example:

  • 1) Load polaris, 2) load model X --> model X shows up very tiny
  • 1) load model X, 2) load polaris, 3) load model X (either as a second instance or after deleting the first instance) --> both instances of model X show up at the expected size

Some example models that get influenced:

  • assassin: www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/assassins_creed.tar.gz
  • tree (btw you can also use this model for testing ticket #404): www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/firtree.tar.gz

values.title: gazebo world state diff performance issues

content.raw:
the block from [World.cc:510](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0c8b89b967826b4f9e45baa57d4cdabc3f8e4c56/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=default#cl-510) to [World.cc:522](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0c8b89b967826b4f9e45baa57d4cdabc3f8e4c56/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=default#cl-522) takes on the average of 0.5ms, longer than next largest resource consumer in `World::Update` [physics update call](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0c8b89b967826b4f9e45baa57d4cdabc3f8e4c56/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=default#cl-493) which averages about 0.4ms for [atlas_sandia_hands.launch](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/src/2f21e05aece754747e8d129dfde0df28675215dd/ros/atlas_utils/launch/atlas_sandia_hands.launch?at=default)

We need to improve performance by either threading this out or throttling it.  Threading out is preferable if it avoids uneven `World::Update` intervals.
content.html:
the block from World.cc:510 to World.cc:522 takes on the average of 0.5ms, longer than next largest resource consumer in World::Update physics update call which averages about 0.4ms for atlas_sandia_hands.launch

We need to improve performance by either threading this out or throttling it. Threading out is preferable if it avoids uneven World::Update intervals.

values.title: polaris steering angle -> vehicle velocity bug

content.raw:
There seems to be a bug with the polaris ranger related to steering angle and the vehicle's velocity (or possibly it's a gazebo bug triggered by polaris). When you set the hand brake to 0, gas pedal to 1, and then gradually set the steering angle from 0 to 2 to 2.5 to 3 to 3.14 everything seems to be fine. But when you go from 0 directly to 3 the car completely stops every few meters. When using a lower gas the "step size" that it stops working at is even lower (e.g. for 0.5 gas it stops working with a 0 -> 2 transition already I think).

This problem does not seem to exist on the golf cart model (the golf cart however does not seem to be able to regulate the gas strength though). I thought it might be related to the friction coefficients the polaris model's wheels have which are missing on the golf cart but even after removing them the same problem persisted. 

This bug also occurs when you have to stop the vehicle while driving at a "high" steering angle and then try to continue driving. You have to go back to 0 steering angle (or somewhere close to maybe, haven't verified whether it has to be exactly 0) in order to recover normal car behaviour.

Video demonstrating the bug (you can see the steering commands sent at the top): http://youtu.be/GLBSdJKZD0I

Same steering command (0 -> 3.14 transition) with golf cart: http://youtu.be/K2Y02CdGP0I
content.html:
There seems to be a bug with the polaris ranger related to steering angle and the vehicle's velocity (or possibly it's a gazebo bug triggered by polaris). When you set the hand brake to 0, gas pedal to 1, and then gradually set the steering angle from 0 to 2 to 2.5 to 3 to 3.14 everything seems to be fine. But when you go from 0 directly to 3 the car completely stops every few meters. When using a lower gas the "step size" that it stops working at is even lower (e.g. for 0.5 gas it stops working with a 0 -> 2 transition already I think).

This problem does not seem to exist on the golf cart model (the golf cart however does not seem to be able to regulate the gas strength though). I thought it might be related to the friction coefficients the polaris model's wheels have which are missing on the golf cart but even after removing them the same problem persisted.

This bug also occurs when you have to stop the vehicle while driving at a "high" steering angle and then try to continue driving. You have to go back to 0 steering angle (or somewhere close to maybe, haven't verified whether it has to be exactly 0) in order to recover normal car behaviour.

Video demonstrating the bug (you can see the steering commands sent at the top): http://youtu.be/GLBSdJKZD0I

Same steering command (0 -> 3.14 transition) with golf cart: http://youtu.be/K2Y02CdGP0I

values.title: gzfactory broken

content.raw:
Using Gazebo 1.3.1 on Ubuntu 12.04 LTS 64 bit.

```
#!c++


gzfactory spawn -f model.sdf
```

produces the error:
```
#!c++
Error [SDF.cc:984] Unable to find value for key[origin]
Error [SDF.cc:738] Missing element description for [origin]
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

for the model.sdf:

```
#!c++

<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.3'>
  <model name="my_robot">
     <static>true</static>
       <link name='chassis'>
        <pose>0 0 .1 0 0 0</pose>

        <collision name='collision'>
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>.4 .2 .1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>

        <visual name='visual'>
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>.4 .2 .1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      </link>
  </model>
</sdf>

```

Either the SDF is wrong, in which case the tutorial [here](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.3/build_robot/mobile_base) needs to be changed, or something's broken with gzfactory.

values.title: gzclient under gazebo shows up empty; second gzclient works properly

content.raw:
[I though that was already ticketed but couldn't find it.]

A bunch of us have been seeing the following problem: run gazebo with a certain world and get gzclient with an empty 3D view.  No ground plane, no sun, no robot, just clouds.  If you leave that running and start a second instance of gzclient, the second one works fine.  Also, if you manipulate the world in the second gzclient (e.g., drag the robot, insert an object), the updated models start to appear in the original gzclient.  It appears as though the first gzclient missed the "initial state" message and only gets diffs thereafter.

My machine is currently reproducing this problem reliably, as is John's.  I'm using gazebo-prerelease-1.4.5 and drcsim-2.0.0 from debs.  To reproduce:

    . /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh
    roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch

I don't get the problem just running gazebo.

Giving high priority to this in the hopes that we can figure it out for Gazebo 1.4.  The workaround is easy enough, but the behavior is annoying and non-intuitive (the first I encountered it, I thought that something had gone terribly wrong and spent time verifying compatibility among versions of everything before somebody told me that it's a known issue and that I just need to restart the client).

Happy to help debug if I'm pointed in the right direction.
content.html:
[I though that was already ticketed but couldn't find it.]

A bunch of us have been seeing the following problem: run gazebo with a certain world and get gzclient with an empty 3D view. No ground plane, no sun, no robot, just clouds. If you leave that running and start a second instance of gzclient, the second one works fine. Also, if you manipulate the world in the second gzclient (e.g., drag the robot, insert an object), the updated models start to appear in the original gzclient. It appears as though the first gzclient missed the "initial state" message and only gets diffs thereafter.

My machine is currently reproducing this problem reliably, as is John's. I'm using gazebo-prerelease-1.4.5 and drcsim-2.0.0 from debs. To reproduce:

. /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh
roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch

I don't get the problem just running gazebo.

Giving high priority to this in the hopes that we can figure it out for Gazebo 1.4. The workaround is easy enough, but the behavior is annoying and non-intuitive (the first I encountered it, I thought that something had gone terribly wrong and spent time verifying compatibility among versions of everything before somebody told me that it's a known issue and that I just need to restart the client).

Happy to help debug if I'm pointed in the right direction.

values.title: Build warnings - comparison between doubles

content.raw:
MsgFactory test spits out warnings on unsafe floating point comparison using the `==` operator which is what gtest uses inside `EXPECT_EQ`. 

A way around this it to do a subtraction between the two and check if the abs value is less than some epsilon.

```
#!c++

In file included from /home/ian/depot/gazebo/gazebo/msgs/test/MsgFactory.cc:18:0:
/home/ian/depot/gazebo/test/gtest/include/gtest/gtest.h: In function ‘testing::AssertionResult testing::internal::CmpHelperEQ(const char*, const char*, const T1&, const T2&) [with T1 = double, T2 = double]’:
/home/ian/depot/gazebo/test/gtest/include/gtest/gtest.h:1353:30:   instantiated from ‘static testing::AssertionResult testing::internal::EqHelper<lhs_is_null_literal>::Compare(const char*, const char*, const T1&, const T2&) [with T1 = double, T2 = double, bool lhs_is_null_literal = false]’
/home/ian/depot/gazebo/gazebo/msgs/test/MsgFactory.cc:73:3:   instantiated from here
/home/ian/depot/gazebo/test/gtest/include/gtest/gtest.h:1316:3: warning: comparing floating point with == or != is unsafe [-Wfloat-equal]

```
content.html:
MsgFactory test spits out warnings on unsafe floating point comparison using the == operator which is what gtest uses inside EXPECT_EQ.

A way around this it to do a subtraction between the two and check if the abs value is less than some epsilon.

In file included from /home/ian/depot/gazebo/gazebo/msgs/test/MsgFactory.cc:18:0:
/home/ian/depot/gazebo/test/gtest/include/gtest/gtest.h: In function ‘testing::AssertionResult testing::internal::CmpHelperEQ(const char*, const char*, const T1&, const T2&) [with T1 = double, T2 = double]’:
/home/ian/depot/gazebo/test/gtest/include/gtest/gtest.h:1353:30:   instantiated from ‘static testing::AssertionResult testing::internal::EqHelper<lhs_is_null_literal>::Compare(const char*, const char*, const T1&, const T2&) [with T1 = double, T2 = double, bool lhs_is_null_literal = false]’
/home/ian/depot/gazebo/gazebo/msgs/test/MsgFactory.cc:73:3:   instantiated from here
/home/ian/depot/gazebo/test/gtest/include/gtest/gtest.h:1316:3: warning: comparing floating point with == or != is unsafe [-Wfloat-equal]

values.title: Transport message latching hard to get right

content.raw:
There have been 3 recent pull requests fixing problems with latching transport messages (pull request #257, pull request #224, pull request #196). Though these problems have mainly been related to gui visualization, there may be other failures that we aren't seeing. How can we improve this?

Some random questions to spur discussion:

Are there low-volume topics that subscribers should always latch to?

Should latching be the default behavior?

Should we have a non-overloaded function call to subscribe with latching, (ie. SubscribeLatched) so that it's easier to grep for latching and non-latching subscribes?
content.html:
There have been 3 recent pull requests fixing problems with latching transport messages (pull request #257, pull request #224, pull request #196). Though these problems have mainly been related to gui visualization, there may be other failures that we aren't seeing. How can we improve this?

Some random questions to spur discussion:

Are there low-volume topics that subscribers should always latch to?

Should latching be the default behavior?

Should we have a non-overloaded function call to subscribe with latching, (ie. SubscribeLatched) so that it's easier to grep for latching and non-latching subscribes?

values.title: ImuSensor should also return accumulated orientation relative to initial imu reference frame

content.html:
Add functions to return imu orientation:

/// \brief get orientation of the IMU relative to the reference pose
public: math::Quaternion GetOrientation() const;

/// \brief Sets the current pose as the  IMU reference pose
public: void SetReferencePose();

we need this to do away with computing IMU data from a link in drcsim.

values.title: gazebo road texture gets stretched over entire road length

content.raw: The road renderer in gazebo stretches a single road over the whole length of a road which causes the road texture to get extremely stretched and lose its original texture (in terms of features). A better solution for this would be to use multiple texture tiles and assign texture coordinates as a function of distance and road width (depending on the width of the road the texture scales so the wrap around depends on the width of the road).
content.html: The road renderer in gazebo stretches a single road over the whole length of a road which causes the road texture to get extremely stretched and lose its original texture (in terms of features). A better solution for this would be to use multiple texture tiles and assign texture coordinates as a function of distance and road width (depending on the width of the road the texture scales so the wrap around depends on the width of the road).

values.title: custom textures for road renderer

content.raw: The road renderer is a great feature, it would be nice if the user could specify custom textures instead of just the hard-coded one to use different kinds of roads with the road tag.
content.html: The road renderer is a great feature, it would be nice if the user could specify custom textures instead of just the hard-coded one to use different kinds of roads with the road tag.

values.title: MIssing dependency: libcegui-mk2-dev

content.raw:
This was discovered while testing the "start simulation" widget on CloudSim 1.2.7 pre-release: gzserver would not start

The dscsim package should depend on it.

```
#!c++

sudo apt-get install libcegui-mk2-dev
```

fixes the problem

```
#!c++
 dpkg -l gazebo-prerelease
```
reports 1.4.6
content.html:
This was discovered while testing the "start simulation" widget on CloudSim 1.2.7 pre-release: gzserver would not start

The dscsim package should depend on it.

sudo apt-get install libcegui-mk2-dev

fixes the problem

 dpkg -l gazebo-prerelease

reports 1.4.6

values.title: Control user camera programmatically

content.raw:
It would be nice to be able to script the location of user camera. One way would be to publish a pose to a gztopic that the user camera would subscribe to and change its pose accordingly.

It would also be nice if you could publish messages using gztopic from the command-line (similar to a rostopic feature).
content.html:
It would be nice to be able to script the location of user camera. One way would be to publish a pose to a gztopic that the user camera would subscribe to and change its pose accordingly.

It would also be nice if you could publish messages using gztopic from the command-line (similar to a rostopic feature).

values.title: Model search function

content.raw:
A search function at the top or bottom of the insert tab would be handy to find objects more easily. 

Something simple like a case insensitive search for a partial string match would make it much easier to find objects when having multiple databases and many objects. The search should keep the database groups but only show the matched objects (one might have objects with the same name in multiple databases so you wouldn't know which object you actually want when you can't see the database it belongs to).
content.html:
A search function at the top or bottom of the insert tab would be handy to find objects more easily.

Something simple like a case insensitive search for a partial string match would make it much easier to find objects when having multiple databases and many objects. The search should keep the database groups but only show the matched objects (one might have objects with the same name in multiple databases so you wouldn't know which object you actually want when you can't see the database it belongs to).

values.title: New shape types

content.raw:
We should consider adding new shape types to gazebo. Here's a list of some shapes, according to which dependencies already support them:

Supported by ODE, Bullet:

* Capsule aka capped cylinder (cylinder with semi-spheres attached to each flat end)

Supported by Bullet:

* Cone
* Ellipsoid (distorted sphere, implemented using btMultiSphereShape)
* Rounded box (also implemented using btMultiSphereShape)
* Convex hull of trimesh (more efficient collision detection than concave trimesh)
content.html:
We should consider adding new shape types to gazebo. Here's a list of some shapes, according to which dependencies already support them:

Supported by ODE, Bullet:

  • Capsule aka capped cylinder (cylinder with semi-spheres attached to each flat end)

Supported by Bullet:

  • Cone
  • Ellipsoid (distorted sphere, implemented using btMultiSphereShape)
  • Rounded box (also implemented using btMultiSphereShape)
  • Convex hull of trimesh (more efficient collision detection than concave trimesh)

values.title: Add optional `default_position` to `<joint>` element

content.raw:
Proposing adding an optional default joint angle to `<joint>` elements:

~~~
<joint name="joint_12" type="revolute">
    <parent>link_1</parent>
    <child>link_2</child>
    <axis>
        <xyz>1.000000 0.000000 0.000000</xyz>
        <default_position>0.0</default_position>
    </axis>
</joint>
~~~

and the corresponding modification to [joint.sdf](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/eaa30596bb7c/gazebo/sdf/1.3/joint.sdf?at=default):
~~~
diff -r eaa30596bb7c gazebo/sdf/1.3/joint.sdf
--- a/gazebo/sdf/1.3/joint.sdf	Fri Feb 01 10:39:15 2013 -0800
+++ b/gazebo/sdf/1.3/joint.sdf	Mon Feb 04 10:40:48 2013 -0800
@@ -31,6 +31,9 @@
     <element name="xyz" type="vector3" default="0 0 1" required="1">
       <description>Represents the x,y,z components of a vector. The vector should be normalized.</description>
     </element>
+    <element name="default_position" type="double" default="0" required="0">
+      <description>Default joint position for this joint axis.  Note the state of the joint specified by state.sdf::model::joint::angle or state.sdf::model::link::pose is used while loading a scene if one is specified instead of default_position.</description>
+    </element>
     <element name="dynamics" required="0">
       <description>An element specifying physical properties of the joint. These values are used to specify modeling properties of the joint, particularly useful for simulation.</description>
       <element name="damping" type="double" default="0" required="0">
~~~

This will be a fallback for joint angle at load time if [joint angle in state.sdf](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/eaa30596bb7c/gazebo/sdf/1.3/state.sdf?at=default#cl-39) has not been specified.
content.html:
Proposing adding an optional default joint angle to <joint> elements:

<joint name="joint_12" type="revolute">
    <parent>link_1</parent>
    <child>link_2</child>
    <axis>
        <xyz>1.000000 0.000000 0.000000</xyz>
        <default_position>0.0</default_position>
    </axis>
</joint>

and the corresponding modification to joint.sdf:

diff -r eaa30596bb7c gazebo/sdf/1.3/joint.sdf
--- a/gazebo/sdf/1.3/joint.sdf  Fri Feb 01 10:39:15 2013 -0800
+++ b/gazebo/sdf/1.3/joint.sdf  Mon Feb 04 10:40:48 2013 -0800
@@ -31,6 +31,9 @@
     <element name="xyz" type="vector3" default="0 0 1" required="1">
       <description>Represents the x,y,z components of a vector. The vector should be normalized.</description>
     </element>
+    <element name="default_position" type="double" default="0" required="0">
+      <description>Default joint position for this joint axis.  Note the state of the joint specified by state.sdf::model::joint::angle or state.sdf::model::link::pose is used while loading a scene if one is specified instead of default_position.</description>
+    </element>
     <element name="dynamics" required="0">
       <description>An element specifying physical properties of the joint. These values are used to specify modeling properties of the joint, particularly useful for simulation.</description>
       <element name="damping" type="double" default="0" required="0">

This will be a fallback for joint angle at load time if joint angle in state.sdf has not been specified.

values.title: Different gz_build macros for DISPLAY and DRI tests

content.raw:
Create two new cmake macros:

 1) gz_build_display_test : for tests that require a display

 2) gz_build_dri_test: for tests that require DRI

gz_build_test will be used for all other tests.
content.html:
Create two new cmake macros:

1) gz_build_display_test : for tests that require a display

2) gz_build_dri_test: for tests that require DRI

gz_build_test will be used for all other tests.

values.title: JointDamping physics regression test is brittle

content.raw:
While adding code to PhysicsTest.SpawnDropCoGOffset physics regression test (commit 5e24c19), I managed to cause a failure of PhysicsTest.JointDampingTest.
~~~
[ RUN      ] PhysicsTest.JointDampingTest
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 1.4.6
...
/home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo/test/regression/physics.cc:584: Failure
Expected: (vel.z) > (-6.51768), actual: -6.5177 vs -6.51768
[  FAILED  ] PhysicsTest.JointDampingTest (2675 ms)
~~~

It's probably a simple matter of adjusting the tolerances on the JointDamping test, but it's strange that adding code to a different test caused this failure.

It's probably a simple matter of adjusting the tolerances on the JointDamping test, but it's strange that adding code to a different test caused this failure.

values.title: Bullet: spheres roll differently along principal axes than on diagonals

In the SpawnDropCoGOffset test, adding spheres with c.o.g. offsets along the x or y axis and then dropping them will lead to the spheres rolling without slip back and forth along the direction of the offset in both ODE and Bullet.

When adding spheres with c.o.g. offsets along a diagonal (ie. both x and y offset are nonzero, as in 687a88c), the spheres roll differently in Bullet, though in ODE they roll back and forth in the direction of the offset.

Video: [diagonal rolling in ODE](https://vimeo.com/58954332)

values.title: Heightmaps cannot be inserted using InsertModelWidget

content.raw:
When I try to add this model in gazebo-1.4.0 I can't see where I am going to put it. But if I click somewhere it appears in GUI. 
After I delete this model in tab "World", the GUI doesn't refresh, and if I try to add new instances of this model I can't see if it was added (and where it was added).

I attached the model file.

The steps to reproduce are:

1) Put the model in GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH

2) Start gazebo

3) Click in the insert tab and choose Terrain model (you can't see the model while move the cursor)

4) Click anywhere in the GUI (the model will be added)

5) In the tab World->Models, delete the terrain instance (the GUI will not refresh)

6) In the tab Insert, try to add another instance of terrain model (the other instance will not displayed)
content.html:
When I try to add this model in gazebo-1.4.0 I can't see where I am going to put it. But if I click somewhere it appears in GUI. After I delete this model in tab "World", the GUI doesn't refresh, and if I try to add new instances of this model I can't see if it was added (and where it was added).

I attached the model file.

The steps to reproduce are:

1) Put the model in GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH

2) Start gazebo

3) Click in the insert tab and choose Terrain model (you can't see the model while move the cursor)

4) Click anywhere in the GUI (the model will be added)

5) In the tab World->Models, delete the terrain instance (the GUI will not refresh)

6) In the tab Insert, try to add another instance of terrain model (the other instance will not displayed)

values.title: IPv6 handled improperly

content.raw:
Test case:

 1) Modify `/etc/hosts` to have the line beginning with `::1` contain `localhost`
 2) Run gzserver. It will never connect to Master

Fix:

  1) Skip over IPv6 addresses in Connection.cc
content.html:
Test case:

1) Modify /etc/hosts to have the line beginning with ::1 contain localhost 2) Run gzserver. It will never connect to Master

Fix:

1) Skip over IPv6 addresses in Connection.cc

values.title: Naming convention for internal functions

content.raw: Should we have a naming convention for internal use functions?
content.html: Should we have a naming convention for internal use functions?

values.title: Update Joint::GetForce to return accumulated result of SetForce at every timestep

content.raw: Currently, `Joint::GetForce` uses `Joint::forceApplied`, which temporarily stores forces applied to the joint when `Joint::SetForce` is called.  Proposing modifying this function to accumulate `Joint::forceApplied` when `Joint::SetForce` is called, and clear on every timestep advance.
content.html: Currently, Joint::GetForce uses Joint::forceApplied, which temporarily stores forces applied to the joint when Joint::SetForce is called. Proposing modifying this function to accumulate Joint::forceApplied when Joint::SetForce is called, and clear on every timestep advance.

values.title: Specify physics engine for gzserver on command-line

content.raw: Currently we maintain separate sdf files for loading the same world with different physics engines. It would be nice if we could optionally specify the physics engine on the command-line to override the default (currently ODE).
content.html: Currently we maintain separate sdf files for loading the same world with different physics engines. It would be nice if we could optionally specify the physics engine on the command-line to override the default (currently ODE).

values.title: Offer "Edit Preferences" option in GUI

content.raw: As the Toolbar grows, users may want to customize the Toolbar. We should offer an Edit  (menu) > Preferences option.
content.html: As the Toolbar grows, users may want to customize the Toolbar. We should offer an Edit (menu) > Preferences option.

values.title: GetWorldLinearVel(pose) has confusing argument

content.raw: The GetWorldLinearVel(math::Pose) function added in pull request #270 has potentially confusing arguments, since the position and rotation elements of pose are treated differently than the pose is typically used. It would be clearer to use two arguments as: GetWorldLinearVel(math::Vector3, math::Quaternion) to avoid confusion.
content.html: The GetWorldLinearVel(math::Pose) function added in pull request #270 has potentially confusing arguments, since the position and rotation elements of pose are treated differently than the pose is typically used. It would be clearer to use two arguments as: GetWorldLinearVel(math::Vector3, math::Quaternion) to avoid confusion.

values.title: model loader checking for hidden directories

content.raw: The newer Gazebo versions seem to also include hidden, unrelated directories in its ``GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`` which then leads to error messages like these (non-fatal but still wrong and confusing): ``Error [InsertModelWidget.cc:252] model.config file is missing in directory["/home/drc/repo/trunk/worlds/drc_models/.svn"]`` (``drc_models`` is in the ``GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH``)
content.html: The newer Gazebo versions seem to also include hidden, unrelated directories in its GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH which then leads to error messages like these (non-fatal but still wrong and confusing): Error [InsertModelWidget.cc:252] model.config file is missing in directory["/home/drc/repo/trunk/worlds/drc_models/.svn"] (drc_models is in the GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH)

values.title: Connection class lacks mutex to protect closing

content.raw: Many of our regression tests fail occasionally on jenkins. I've managed to catch a few backtraces (see #328), and each one I've seen involves a race condition on closing the socket. I noticed that the Connection class has mutexes to protect new connections, writes, and reads, but there should also be a mutex for closing connections.
content.html: Many of our regression tests fail occasionally on jenkins. I've managed to catch a few backtraces (see #328), and each one I've seen involves a race condition on closing the socket. I noticed that the Connection class has mutexes to protect new connections, writes, and reads, but there should also be a mutex for closing connections.

values.title: Text topic viewer doesn't handle image data well

content.raw: If you view a text topic in the topic viewer (~/pose/info for example), you can then change topics from the drop down box. If there happens to be a camera publishing, then you can see and select that topic (eg. ~/camera/link/camera/image), though it will make the client barely usable. We should disable image topics from the text viewer.
content.html: If you view a text topic in the topic viewer (~/pose/info for example), you can then change topics from the drop down box. If there happens to be a camera publishing, then you can see and select that topic (eg. ~/camera/link/camera/image), though it will make the client barely usable. We should disable image topics from the text viewer.

values.title: Force stop model database cache update

content.raw:
The model database cache update can take a bit of time. If gazebo is quite while it's updating, the shutdown hangs until libcurl completes.

This should be improved by using curl_multi:
http://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/c/libcurl-multi.html
content.html:
The model database cache update can take a bit of time. If gazebo is quite while it's updating, the shutdown hangs until libcurl completes.

This should be improved by using curl_multi: http://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/c/libcurl-multi.html

values.title: BulletHingeJoint::GetVelocity not implemented

content.raw: This function is needed for velocity control. Bullet does not provide a function like this internally, but it can be implemented by taking the difference in the angular velocity of each body and dotting along the joint axis.
content.html: This function is needed for velocity control. Bullet does not provide a function like this internally, but it can be implemented by taking the difference in the angular velocity of each body and dotting along the joint axis.

values.title: Make joint axis reference frame relative to child

content.raw:
In the sdf documentation, the [<joint><axis> element is listed as using the joint frame](http://gazebosim.org/sdf/dev.html#axis245), when in practice it uses the model frame (see [Joint.cc:175-191](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/903ed6a21a1d/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc?at=default#cl-175)).

I recommend fixing the code to match what the documentation currently says, rather than just changing the documentation, since it will simplify model creation to fix this.

We should test the PR2, Atlas, Polaris, and other models to ensure that fixing this bug does not break things.
content.html:
In the sdf documentation, the <joint><axis> element is listed as using the joint frame, when in practice it uses the model frame (see Joint.cc:175-191).

I recommend fixing the code to match what the documentation currently says, rather than just changing the documentation, since it will simplify model creation to fix this.

We should test the PR2, Atlas, Polaris, and other models to ensure that fixing this bug does not break things.

content.html:
One issue: all measurements are taken relative to the origin of the world. Test by opening sdf/worlds/empty_bullet.world and inserting a hokuyo sensor. If the hokuyo is inserted with a positive x position, it will see itself.

values.title: Threaded plugins

content.raw:
See here: [http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/1317/drcsim-how-shall-we-jointly-agree-on-simulation/?answer=1326#post-id-1326](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/1317/drcsim-how-shall-we-jointly-agree-on-simulation/?answer=1326#post-id-1326)

The first step is to profile Gazebo to determine if plugins are indeed a big drain on Gazebo.

values.title: Rounded axis values in BulletHingeJoint::Attach

content.raw:
The axis values in [BulletHingeJoint::Attach at lines 98-99](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/9f19d002ffe9d0a474a5b01f34156b9283bb42b1/gazebo/physics/bullet/BulletHingeJoint.cc#cl-98) are rounded when they should be normalized.

A joint test should be created that creates joints using axes that aren't aligned with the world frame axis.
content.html:
The axis values in BulletHingeJoint::Attach at lines 98-99 are rounded when they should be normalized.

A joint test should be created that creates joints using axes that aren't aligned with the world frame axis.

values.title: Bullet self collide not yet functional

content.raw: The self-collide functionality is not yet implemented in bullet, which is causing problems with using the Atlas model in bullet, since many of the Atlas links are colliding with each other. This should be implemented, tested, and set to use the same defaults as ODE.
content.html: The self-collide functionality is not yet implemented in bullet, which is causing problems with using the Atlas model in bullet, since many of the Atlas links are colliding with each other. This should be implemented, tested, and set to use the same defaults as ODE.

values.title: assert calls in gazebo code

content.html:
I just ran across an assert call in ODECollision.cc:106. A recursive grep identifies a few more assert calls (I've filtered out a few irrelevant lines):

$ grep -rnI assert gazebo
gazebo/gui/GLWidget.cc:729:  assert(q_parent);
gazebo/rendering/MovableText.cc:274:  assert(this->font);
gazebo/rendering/MovableText.cc:275:  assert(!this->material.isNull());
gazebo/rendering/MovableText.cc:609:  assert(this->font);
gazebo/rendering/MovableText.cc:610:  assert(!this->material.isNull());
gazebo/rendering/MovableText.cc:636:  assert(this->camera);
gazebo/rendering/MovableText.cc:645:  assert(mParentNode);
gazebo/rendering/MovableText.cc:724:  assert(!this->material.isNull());
gazebo/rendering/deferred_shading/LightMaterialGenerator.hh:258:        assert(false && "Permutation must have a light type");
gazebo/common/MeshCSG.cc:196:  assert(gts_surface_inter_check(si, &closed));
gazebo/common/SkeletonAnimation.cc:143:  assert(t >= 0.0 && t <= 1.0);
gazebo/common/SystemPaths.cc:22:#include <assert.h>
gazebo/math/Matrix3.hh:20:#include <assert.h>
gazebo/math/Matrix3.hh:88:                assert(_row < 3);
gazebo/math/Matrix3.hh:97:                assert(_row < 3);
gazebo/math/RotationSpline.cc:54:  assert (_fromIndex < this->points.size() && "fromIndex out of bounds");
gazebo/math/RotationSpline.cc:157:  assert (_index < this->points.size() && "Point index is out of bounds!!");
gazebo/math/RotationSpline.cc:176:  assert (_index < this->points.size() && "Point index is out of bounds!!");
gazebo/math/RotationSpline.hh:47:        /// \return a quaternion (out of bound index result in assertion)
gazebo/math/Matrix4.hh:20:#include <assert.h>
gazebo/math/Matrix4.hh:163:                assert(_row < 4);
gazebo/math/Matrix4.hh:170:                assert(_row < 4);
gazebo/physics/ode/ODECollision.cc:106:    assert(dGeomGetSpace(this->collisionId) != 0);
gazebo/physics/ode/ODEMultiRayShape.cc:131:    assert(collision1 && collision2);
gazebo/physics/ode/ODEMultiRayShape.cc:147:      assert(rayCollision == NULL);

We should evaluate whether these should be assertions, and switch them over to GZ_ASSERT if so.

values.title: undefined reference linker errors for functions in QTest

content.raw:
With the latest gazebo version from the default branch, I get linker errors due to undefined references to functions in the QTest namespace. The target causing the linker error is the gzclient executable.

Here is the output from `make gzclient`:
```
CMakeFiles/gzclient.dir/Actions.cc.o: In function `qWait':
/usr/include/qt4/QtTest/qtestsystem.h:70: undefined reference to `QTest::qSleep(int)'
CMakeFiles/gzclient.dir/Actions.cc.o: In function `simulateEvent':
/usr/include/qt4/QtTest/qtestkeyboard.h:76: undefined reference to `QTest::defaultKeyDelay()'
/usr/include/qt4/QtTest/qtestkeyboard.h:77: undefined reference to `QTest::defaultKeyDelay()'
/usr/include/qt4/QtTest/qtestkeyboard.h:84: undefined reference to `QTest::qWarn(char const*)'
CMakeFiles/gzclient.dir/Actions.cc.o: In function `mouseEvent':
/usr/include/qt4/QtTest/qtestmouse.h:77: undefined reference to `QTest::defaultMouseDelay()'
/usr/include/qt4/QtTest/qtestmouse.h:78: undefined reference to `QTest::defaultMouseDelay()'
/usr/include/qt4/QtTest/qtestmouse.h:124: undefined reference to `QTest::qWarn(char const*)'
[...]
```
I attached the full output log file as it is too big for inline posting.

I am compiling in debug mode in Ubuntu precise amd64 following the instructions from [the Gazebo wiki](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/1.4/install#Compiling_From_Source). The libqt4-test-dev package is installed (version 4.8.1-0ubuntu4.3). I noticed that the `QT_QTTEST_LIBRARY_DEBUG` cmake variable is set to `NOTFOUND` in my CMakeCache.txt:

```
//Path to a file.
QT_QTTEST_INCLUDE_DIR:PATH=/usr/include/qt4/QtTest

//The Qt QTTEST library
QT_QTTEST_LIBRARY:STRING=/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtTest.so

//Path to a library.
QT_QTTEST_LIBRARY_DEBUG:FILEPATH=QT_QTTEST_LIBRARY_DEBUG-NOTFOUND

//Path to a library.
QT_QTTEST_LIBRARY_RELEASE:FILEPATH=/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtTest.so
```
